content: I am not very religious but wtf? Most people wouldnt know what IHS was anyway. Besides that inscription was several feet above his head so the flag excuse is lame and smoke and mirrors. Sorry WH and PrezBo we are a Christian nation no matter how you try to cover it up quote: 'http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/04/16/georgetown-university-hid-religious-symbols-white-house-request/' The monogram IHS, whose letters spell out the name of Jesus, and which normally perches above the stage in Gaston Hall where the president spoke, was covered over with what appeared to be black wood during the address… “Decisions made about the backdrop for the speech were made to have a consistent background of American flags, which is standard for many presidential events,” said White House spokesman Shin Inouye in a statement released Thursday… Bill Donohue, president of the Catholic League, accused the university of “cowardice” for acceding to the White House, and criticized Obama’s team for asking a religious school to “neuter itself” before the president made his address. The offending IHS inscription. The black plywood cover for that offensive inscription. With the flag excuse.
quote: 'http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/04/16/georgetown-university-hid-religious-symbols-white-house-request/' The monogram IHS, whose letters spell out the name of Jesus, and which normally perches above the stage in Gaston Hall where the president spoke, was covered over with what appeared to be black wood during the address… “Decisions made about the backdrop for the speech were made to have a consistent background of American flags, which is standard for many presidential events,” said White House spokesman Shin Inouye in a statement released Thursday… Bill Donohue, president of the Catholic League, accused the university of “cowardice” for acceding to the White House, and criticized Obama’s team for asking a religious school to “neuter itself” before the president made his address.
reply: I am not very religious but wtf? Most people wouldnt know what IHS was anyway. Besides that inscription was several feet above his head so the flag excuse is lame and smoke and mirrors. Sorry WH and PrezBo we are a Christian nation no matter how you try to cover it up  The offending IHS inscription. The black plywood cover for that offensive inscription. With the flag excuse.

content: The President was making an address to the nation, not leading a prayer service. He was asked to speak from that location, which is fine, but we don't need the mixed imagery of our elected officials and religion, as if one was endorsing the other. Personally, I would have preferred that they simply pick a secular location for the speech, but seeing as they didn't, I see no problem with redecorating a podium and backdrop to make it appropriate for a secular political speech. And Gunny, you can scream and cry all you want that this is a "Christian nation," and it's true that the majority of Americans come from one of several Christian backgrounds (although not all of those are particularly religious), but our government is NOT affiliated with any religion, and it shouldn't be. Our government, and our nation as a political (not cultural) entity, is secular. Likewise, as a comparative example, Turkey is a culturally Muslim nation, but has an absolutely secular government, and the people of Turkey are quite proud of that. Once upon a time, Americans used to be proud of our secular government and freedom of religion. This move to shove religion into politics comes in waves throughout our history, and it's always irritating when it does. Good for our current President, not shoving religion down the throats of Americans.

content: quote: Originally posted by navy8086: quote: Good for our current President, not shoving religion down the throats of Americans. As opposed to trying to rip it from our hearts and minds? Just more pandering to the aethist left. If the symbol was "offensive" maybe he should have AVOIDED that venue. What part of "not demonstrating endorsement of a SPECIFIC religion" has anything to do with atheism? Being secular does not mean atheist. Here's an analogy for you: Every other Tuesday, I run a safety training orientation for new employees here. I don't have any need to preface the training session with a religious invocation, or display a religious symbol in conjunction with the class, in order to do my job. That doesn't make me an atheist - it means that I don't need to shove religion into every little thing I do. Even more strictly, as an elected American official, President Obama has an OBLIGATION to remain officially non-biased towards or against any religion. When he speaks, he's addressing ALL Americans, not just the Christian ones. For that matter, when he speaks, he can be seen as addressing the whole world. What's so wrong with ensuring that the venue and discussions stay focused on the practical, functional, political issues as opposed to presenting a speech in front of a clear symbol of Christian theology? The only people who take issue with that are the people who are obsessed with pushing the false notion that our nation is a Christian nation.
quote: Originally posted by navy8086: quote: Good for our current President, not shoving religion down the throats of Americans. As opposed to trying to rip it from our hearts and minds? Just more pandering to the aethist left. If the symbol was "offensive" maybe he should have AVOIDED that venue.
reply: What part of "not demonstrating endorsement of a SPECIFIC religion" has anything to do with atheism? Being secular does not mean atheist. Here's an analogy for you: Every other Tuesday, I run a safety training orientation for new employees here. I don't have any need to preface the training session with a religious invocation, or display a religious symbol in conjunction with the class, in order to do my job. That doesn't make me an atheist - it means that I don't need to shove religion into every little thing I do. Even more strictly, as an elected American official, President Obama has an OBLIGATION to remain officially non-biased towards or against any religion. When he speaks, he's addressing ALL Americans, not just the Christian ones. For that matter, when he speaks, he can be seen as addressing the whole world. What's so wrong with ensuring that the venue and discussions stay focused on the practical, functional, political issues as opposed to presenting a speech in front of a clear symbol of Christian theology? The only people who take issue with that are the people who are obsessed with pushing the false notion that our nation is a Christian nation.
